The company has rebased FY19e trading EBITDA
to £335-345 million from consensus estimates of £391 million. Combined capex and opex investment of £45 million in Roadside and Insurance is expected in FY19, with 65 new roadside patrols, 200 new call centre agents and more competitive insurance pricing. Including this, in FY19 the company expects to generate in excess of £80 million Free Cash Flow to Equity in FY20e (consensus £152m) and in excess of £100 million pa thereafter (c.14% FCFE yield).

red i didnt say that. i said a year or two.
Pseudonym I just said we were overdue.
11:15 am
BE11:16am

The company has provided guidance for the revenue and trading EBITDA CAGR between FY19 to FY23. They expect group revenue to grow between 3-5% and EBITDA growth of between 5-8%. Insurance revenue is expected to grow at 6-9% and trading EBITDA at 9-14% as the group adds more solvency capital to its underwriting business. Roadside Assistance revenue is expected to grow at 2-5% and trading EBITDA at 3-6% with key targets to return membership back to growth, 50% of all members to registered on the AA app and a 20% reduction in breakdowns reported through contact centres.

We expect the magnitude of the guidance change and 12-14% downgrade to consensus FY19e EBITDA expectations to result in further near-term share price pressure. Additionally, the cut in the dividend could result in some shareholder churn for income focused investors. However, even at current levels we view the shares to be significantly undervalued and see opportunity for a re-rating as the new management team executes on its strategy over the next 2 years.

BE11:19am

There is no change to 2018 estimates, but 2019 EBITDA and EPS estimate reduced 16% and 38%. We expect the DPS to be cut from 9.3p in FY 2017 to 2.0p in 2019. Revised 2019 net debt / EBITDA is 7.8x. As we expected, there is no silver bullet for the debt. But with a bit better earnings momentum and growth the market might become a little more forgiving on the debt. The IT transformation will extend into FY 20. At Roadside the strategy is to innovate through Car Genie etc. and grow. At Insurance the strategy is to grow EBITDA e.g. through IHP, with greater focus on non-members. The Driving businesses remain core and we expect the acquisition of AA Cars to complete in early March. The long process of de-leveraging just got longer. We reduce our target price from 250p to 100p, a revised CY 2018 FCFe yield of 4.2%

red @Pseudonymunless a black swan event it doesnt just happen overnight. its a case of working the floor and seeing when folks start getting overstretched. still a lot of cash backing this move. there are record loan applications now, these will take time to feed through to actual purchases and then usually the fastest period to a fall off in growth from there is 12 months, so thats why i say 12 months at the earliest. it may be longer as rates are still supportive in europe and euro isnt too strong yet either.

BE11:28am

Metro bank 4Q17 underlying PBT of £8.3m is up 15% QoQ but 18% lower than our forecasts (and c50% of £16.8m). Revenues increased by 8% QoQ to £84.6m driven by loan growth of 12% to £9.6bn with customer deposit net interest margin (CD NIM) falling by 1bp to 2.21% (PGe 2.27%). Within this Metro recorded a further gain of £1.4m on sale of securities. Deposits in the quarter increased by 8% to £11.7bn with a loan-to-deposit ratio of 82% and cost of deposit increasing by 2bp to 52bp. Credit quality worsened in 4Q17 although cost of risk for FY2017 was 11bp. CET1 ratio fell by 180bp QoQ to 15.3% (PGe 17.1%) due to higher RWAs. New 2023 RoE target is 17-19% which compares to previous c18% guidance for 2022.With poor results and Metro bank trading at FY2017 P/TBV of 3.3 for reported RoE of 1.2%, we believe that the returns potential is more than discounted in the current share price.

red @FATDAZits the fact their sales are largely outside of europe. thats the theme with the shares they have highlighted as being short.
BE11:33am

MTRO reported its first full-year of profit in 2017 and profits continue to grow, underpinned by double-digit loan and deposit growth qoq. The outlook for 2020 has been tweaked but is largely unchanged. In 2023, MTRO expects ROE to reach 17–19% on an expanded network of 140–160 stores (up from 55 stores in 2017 and c.100 for 2020), a target which we believe it can meet by continuing its current strategy. Metro is preparing its bid for the Williams & Glyn alternative remedies package to accelerate its reach and offering to serve more UK businesses, which we do not believe are incorporated in the guidance due to the uncertainty. We expect capital to fall due to the high growth, but the IRB application on residential mortgages could compensate for this, or if not, additional equity issuance could be warranted to fund the exceptional growth rates.
We maintain our Sector Perform rating given the limited upside potential at the current share price, even though it is our opinion that Metro is a long-term, high-growth, low-risk story. Our 4,000p price target values Metro at 19x 2020E EPS, a multiple we find appropriate given the company’s unique characteristics.

Despite obvious obstacles around Tobacco, private equity firms have had significant interest in the past in the sector, due to its cash generation. Market conditions, and Imperial’s valuation, could now bring Tobacco back into focus, despite the potential deal’s size. Even in a “managed liquidation” of Imperial, we estimate a reasonable IRR and cash-on-cash return. An IPO of a streamlined Imperial would be even more attractive, should market conditions permit.

Otter @pop have Glen done the conference call, and is there a transcript I can read?
11:40 am
BE11:40am

China National Tobacco Corp is now as likely a bidder as Japan Tobacco, in our view. Industry volumes and tax revenues in China are under severe pressure, and a move at this time would be consistent with years of preparation of a “going out” strategy, already seen in other industries. Meanwhile, JT could buy Imperial at a 45% premium to its current share price, enhancing EPS by 30% by Y4, and reducing net debt/EBITDA to 2x at that stage (net of disposals and keeping the government stake at 33%); JT is unlikely to signal such a move.

BE11:49am

Glencore reported a modest miss in 2017 results versus our estimates, but in line with consensus with EBITDA of USD14.8bn vs MSe at USD15.4 (consensus at USD14.8bn). Guidance increased but is below our estimates, driven by lower EBITDA from coal as price discounts seem to be higher than we expected. Spot EBITDA and FCF for 2018 of USD19.7bn and USD9.6bn are below our estimates of USD21bn and USD11.4bn (on Glencore’s definition or USD9.2bn FCF on IFRS basis) and higher than the Group’s guidance in December of USD16.2bn and USD7.4bn respectively. The main driver vs us is lower EBITDA from coal, which seems to be driven by a higher than expected price discount. Cash taxes and interest are also slightly higher.

BE11:50am

The proposed dividend of 20cents per share or 49% payout ratio on 2017 EPS (4% yield annualised) is in-line with MSe at 20.7p. Net debt was USD10.7bn lower than MSe at USD11.1bn (consensus of USD11.0bn and target range USD10-16bn). Glencore’s FCF valuation looks attractive at 9.7% FCF yield 2018 rising to 14% in 2019 on our estimate on spot versus the weighted average of the London listed diversified companies at a 10% and 13%. However, that partly reflects the very significant contribution of the African copper operations with EBITDA USD2.9bn and USD4.4bn in 2018 and 2019 (out of USD21 and USD23bn in total) where regulatory risk appears to be rising.

2018 is a key year for FirstGroup – as it gets its bond refinancing underway it needs to decide what sort of business it wants to be and thus its future capex and capital needs and hence what its future capital structure and growth/yield strategy should be.

BE11:57am

[E]ven with initial refinancing underway, there was no new strategic vision for the group yet. FY results are due on 31st May, which would be the next opportunity to outline how the company thinks about is portfolio of business in a way to optimise capital structure and shareholder returns. If there is none, we question whether the CEO and board really have any long-term vision for the group – rather than firefighting divisional profits performance spread across 5 divisions dispersed across ~7 time zones.

Lloyds Banking Group (LLOY) has delivered a solid set of 2017 results, with underlying PBT broadly in line with market. The CET 1 ratio of 13.9% is robust and supports the movement to a c.14% CET 1 management target together with the increases in ordinary dividend and the £1bn buyback. The strategic plan will see a significant increase in investment costs to deliver ROTE of 14-15%, with the targets provided being somewhat ahead of expectations, which should support modest increases to underlying forecasts.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

Lloyds has just released 4Q17 results. All-in, we believe 4Q17 numbers are broadly in line, with a slight miss in PBT driven mainly by weaker other income. Capital return is in line with consensus, with the special DPS paid in the form of a buyback. In terms of new guidance, we highlight that the group expects NIM to remain broadly flat at the 4Q17 level (in line with consensus). Over the medium term, it expects NIM to remain resilient amid gradual rate rises (to 1.25% by end 2020). All other targets appear broadly consistent with consensus, except for asset quality, which is around 10 bp lower. The group raised its capital threshold guidance to c.14% (vs. 13%) and retained its ROTE guidance of c.14-15%. All, we see this as broadly in line with consensus and would expect a muted share price reaction

PM12:03pm

A balanced approach to distributing (part of) surplus capital generation; the
aggregate dividend is flat at 3.05p (i.e. the 0.5p “special” in 2016 has been
subsumed into the “ordinary” in 2017), augmented by a £1bn share buyback
programme. In the round, this equates to a 4.4p payout vs our 4.5p forecast, so
largely as expected, but with CET1 capital strengthened to 14.1%. Q4 2017 u/l PBT
of £1.9bn 4% below consensus (£2.0bn) entirely due to “Other Income”. BUY.
